channel.title: U.S. News - Education
channel.description: US News Education provides rankings of over 1,400 best colleges and universities and hundreds of best graduate school programs. Learn how to pay for college and get advice on the admissions process.

item.title: Online Summer Classes Discounted for Coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Emma Kerr
item.description: These online platforms provide classes like Introduction to Computer Science and The Science of Well-Being for free or at a low cost.

item.title: How to Learn Python: A U.S. News Guide
item.dc:creator: Carlos Soto
item.description: If you want to learn Python, a number of free or low-cost resources can help you get started.

item.title: How to Learn Data Science: A U.S. News Guide
item.dc:creator: Whitney Blair Wyckoff
item.description: An array of free and low-cost classes allow you to learn data science skills on your own time.

item.title: Project Management Courses: A U.S. News Guide
item.dc:creator: Ali Follman
item.description: Courses in project management prepare you for certifications that differentiate you from your peers.

item.title: Find an ACT Tutor
item.dc:creator: Bob Musinski
item.description: Find an ACT tutor who will give your student the confidence and strategies to succeed.

item.title: Find an SAT Tutor
item.dc:creator: Bob Musinski
item.description: Free SAT test prep options are available, but some parents may opt to hire a tutor to help their child study.

item.title: How to Learn Spanish: A U.S. News Guide
item.dc:creator: Kara Coleman Fields
item.description: Find the best way to learn Spanish for your budget and learning style.

item.title: Finding a High School Tutor
item.dc:creator: Bob Musinski
item.description: Discover how to find the right high school tutor for your student. Explore in-home, online & free services to help make the right decision. Learn more.

item.title: Financial Literacy for College Students
item.dc:creator: Beverly Harzog
item.description: Improve your financial literacy while in college. Learn how to budget, pick up the basics of credit, saving and investing.

item.title: College Road Trip: Indiana
item.dc:creator: Brian Burnsed

item.title: College Road Trip: California
item.dc:creator: Brian Burnsed

item.title: College Road Trip: Georgia
item.dc:creator: Brian Burnsed

item.title: Improving Instruction on Instruction in Education Grad Schools
item.dc:creator: Jessica Calefati
item.description: Few schools prepare teachers for life in the classroom, research shows.

item.title: The New Doctors in the House
item.dc:creator: Bernadine Healy, M.D.
item.description: How nurses are evolving into far bigger roles at hospitals.

item.title: Bringing Better Health to Rural America
item.dc:creator: January W. Payne
item.description: The nation's small towns need more physicians, and med schools aim to fill the gap.

item.title: The Science Rankings Methodology
item.dc:creator: Sam Flanigan
item.description: How we rank graduate programs in the sciences

item.title: Business School: Teaching More Than Work Ethic
item.dc:creator: Matthew Bandyk
item.description: Tomorrow's corporate leaders are learning business skills and social values at B-schools.

item.title: The Business School Rankings Methodology
item.dc:creator: Sam Flanigan
item.description: How we rank graduate business schools

item.title: Bitten by the Green Design Bug
item.dc:creator: Thomas K. Grose
item.description: Engineering students flock to sustainable design, and schools aim for green waters.

item.title: Colleges Where Need for Aid Can Hurt Admission Odds
item.dc:creator: Kim Clark
item.description: See which schools are most likely to admit and you and give you financial aid.

item.title: Government Helps Low-Income Grad Students Pay for School
item.dc:creator: Kim Clark
item.description: Loans to be capped at 15 percent of income, and those entering public service may get loans forgiven.

item.title: Medical Schools Fight the War Against Disease
item.dc:creator: Carol Frey
item.description: Epidemiologists go straight to the source, then sift their data one clue at a time.

item.title: Business Schools Look for Different Kinds of Students
item.dc:creator: Alison Go
item.description: Admissions offices are pursuing more women and minority candidates.

item.title: Aerospace Engineering Searches for New Talent
item.dc:creator: Thomas K. Grose
item.description: As more baby boomers reach retirement, demand for qualified graduates is on the rise.

item.title: How Technology Is Changing the Medical Profession
item.dc:creator: Bernadine Healy, M.D.
item.description: Clinical practice guidelines, electronic medical records, and population science are revolutionary.

item.title: Picking the Right School for an Education Grad Degree
item.dc:creator: Jessica Calefati
item.description: Is it more important to go to a great school or a school near where you want to teach?

item.title: America's Best Colleges: Most International Students
item.description: The percent of undergraduates who are international.

item.title: America's Best Colleges: Freshman Retention Rates
item.description: The average proportion of freshmen who return the following fall.

item.title: America's Best Colleges: Economic Diversity Among Top Schools
item.description: Percentage of undergraduates receiving federal Pell grants at the Top 25 schools.

item.title: America's Best Colleges: Economic Diversity
item.description: Percentage of undergraduates receiving federal Pell grants.

item.title: America's Best Colleges: Best Values
item.description: These colleges give the best bang for your buck.

item.title: Cheaper, Bigger, and Cooler Student Loans
item.dc:creator: Kim Clark
item.description: New federal standards ease some of the financial pressure for students and their parents.

item.title: Colleges Drop Their Loan Programs
item.dc:creator: Kim Clark
item.description: Administrators at more than 250 public colleges have opted out of the Stafford loan program.

item.title: The Impact of the Virginia Tech Attack
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Terrell
item.description: One consequence of the attack is the increased speed with which colleges respond to threats.

item.title: Cuts in European-Language Studies
item.dc:creator: Lucia Graves
item.description: As more students study Arabic and Chinese, European-language departments are suffering cutbacks.

item.title: Hot Tips for Law School Students
item.description: Specialization isn't the only way to gain practical know-how in law school.

item.title: Hot Tips for a Graduate Degree in Education
item.description: Smart Choices Special Ed. The number of teachers in this specialty is forecast to rise almost 15% by 2016. At some schools (e.g., Vanderbilt...

item.title: New Ways to Get a Degree in Education
item.dc:creator: Lucia Graves
item.description: Options include salaried training, condensed course, and flexible schedules.

item.title: Getting Business School Skills While in Law School
item.dc:creator: Emma Schwartz
item.description: Law school students can choose joint programs and special courses.

item.title: Changes for the GRE Exam This Fall
item.dc:creator: Lucia Graves
item.description: The fill-in-the-blank questions get trickier, and some questions don't give any choices at all.

item.title: Playing Your Cards Right
item.dc:creator: Kim Clark
item.description: The stakes in the financial aid game are higher than ever.

item.title: Loans Are as Tricky as Ever
item.dc:creator: Kimberly Palmer
item.description: Colleges break links with lenders but now give less guidance.

item.title: The New Rules of Finding Aid
item.dc:creator: Kimberly Palmer
item.description: Codes of conduct and pending legislation are changing loan options for students and parents.

item.title: Nickel and Diming Your Kids to College
item.dc:creator: Paul J. Lim
item.description: Small rebates from retailers are just another way parents can fund ever expanding 529 plans.

item.title: Learning Economics 101
item.dc:creator: Emily Brandon
item.description: Schools expect students to work part time. So do parents.

item.title: How to 'Leverage' Your Aid
item.dc:creator: Kim Clark
item.description: You can get more dough by pitting schools against one another.

item.title: SAT Scores Drop for the Second Year in a Row
item.dc:creator: Alex Kingsbury
item.description: The College Board reports a gender gap in the writing section and a rise in students with disabilities.
